Replying to @_leilaura 2018-02-11 09:21
@_leilaura @Netlify @smashingconf It's worth making sure that the version of ruby used by @Netlify during your builds, is the same as in your local builds. You can define that with a .ruby_version file. https://t.co/oJRWUre5lB

2018-02-08 16:39
Frustrating to run out of time in my #SmashingConf workshop leaving only 120s to talk about A/B testing on @Netlify. On the other hand it only took us 90s to set up a 50/50 split test of 2 branches, push to the global CDN, and confirm we could see both options behaving "as prod"

Replying to @simonmcmanus 2018-02-08 16:19
@simonmcmanus @Netlify @greenkeeperio You can fire webhooks based on different events such as a successful/failed build. And you can trigger builds on different branches via an incoming web hooks. So it is more like you have the Lego pieces to make this, rather than having the specific feature you mentioned.
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
2018-02-08 16:13
SO many valuable points in @aemcknig's #SmashingConf talk. We often overlook the importance of creating the a culture that values performance in favour of focus on the details of how to do so technically. One can't succeed without the other. https://t.co/gHEd8UuhCS

Replying to @simonmcmanus 2018-02-08 16:04
@simonmcmanus @Netlify Looks to me like these tests could run in a build in a project on @netlify, which you trigger with a webhook whenever the target site finishes a successful build (of master/branch/pr whatever. (Just my first thought after a peep while in a talk at smashing though!)
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @EugeneMolari 2018-02-08 15:51
@EugeneMolari @Netlify Yep. The gulp task called get:tweets fetches tweets from twitter's API and saves then to a file in the project. Then the build runs @GoHugoIO to generate the site, which uses the tweets it finds in data/tweets.yml to populate some of the templates.
